block.p: Israelis and Palestinians To Meet at Camp David President Clinton said Prime Minister Ehud Barak and Yasir Arafat had agreed to meet at Camp David next week for a summit conference intended to help frame the peace agreement that they hope to reach by September. Mr. Clinton said that the two leaders would face the ''most profound questions'' and that success was not guaranteed.

Iranian Jews' Kin See Clinton Relatives of some of the 10 Jewish men sentenced to prison in Iran on espionage charges met privately with President Clinton at the White House in hope of building pressure against the verdicts. Mr. Clinton has condemned the prison sentences.

A Fungus to Fight Drug Crops Under pressure from the United States, Colombia has reluctantly agreed to take the first step toward developing a powerful biological herbicide against the coca and heroin-poppy fields that are spreading almost unchecked across the Colombian countryside, officials said.

Preview of Missile Defense Test The Pentagon described how a mock warhead is to thunder aloft tomorrow night and how a $30 million rocket will try to destroy it in a high-altitude collision. If the test succeeds, President Clinton may order the building of the first phase of a $60 billion system to defend American soil from missile attacks.
A group of 50 Nobel laureates signed an open letter to President Clinton urging him to reject the proposed missile defense system, saying the plan is wasteful and dangerous.

Sierra Leone Diamond Ban The Security Council voted to impose a worldwide ban on the purchase of rough diamonds from Sierra Leone until its government can establish a system to certify the origin of stones being exported and begins to assert its authority over the diamond fields. Most of Sierra Leone's diamonds are under the control of rebels who smuggle the rough stones out of the country and use the proceeds to buy guns and other war materiel.

Effort to Protect Children President Clinton signed two international agreements, one intended to prevent anyone under 18 from being sent to war and the other to protect children from exploitation by the sex trade and other forms of human trafficking.

Slight, and Rare, Decline In California Prison Rolls The California state prison system, which led the huge national prison-building boom for years, has recorded its first decline in inmate population in more than two decades, to 161,401 inmates in June, 360 fewer than in June 1999. The drop, though tiny, has already caused some officials to say it is time for California to suspend its prison buildup.

A Vote for Impeachment A committee of New Hampshire lawmakers voted to recommend that the full House impeach Chief Justice David Brock of the State Supreme Court based on accusations that he had committed perjury as he defended himself against charges of ethical improprieties. But the committee decided against impeaching or reprimanding two other justices who were also accused of ethical missteps.

Bush Addresses Hispanic Group Gov. George W. Bush told members of the National Council of La Raza, one of the nation's largest and most influential Hispanic groups, that he was on a mission to topple any stereotypes that Republicans are insensitive to minority groups and new immigrants. And he sought to demonstrate his own compassion by proposing to spend an additional $100 million in annual federal spending to expedite foreigners' applications to immigrate.
No-Shows for Summer Classes Officials said the opening of summer school in New York City went smoothly, though a check of a third of the schools showed an average of 40 percent of students absent.

Union Rejects Bonus Policy Delegates to the National Education Association convention broke with their leaders and rejected the use of job performance evaluations in paying bonuses. Many rank-and-file members had expressed concern that the practice was unfair to teachers and to the children who most need good teachers.
Gustaw Herling The author of ''A World Apart,'' a powerful account of life and death in the Soviet network of prisons and labor camps, was 81.

A Newspaper Apologizes For Long-Ago Slave Ads The Hartford Courant, the largest newspaper in Connecticut, published a front-page article in which it apologized for having published advertisements in the 18th and 19th centuries for the sale of slaves. Previously, the newspaper had reported an apology by the locally based insurance giant Aetna for its having issued insurance policies on slaves in the 1850's.

Harsher Penalties Sought Criticism of the Police Department's handling of the Central Park sex attacks intensified as prominent female politicians expressed dissatisfaction with punishments meted out thus far to officers accused of misconduct or lapses in judgment.

Victors in Quarterfinals Andre Agassi will face Patrick Rafter in the men's semifinals at Wimbledon tomorrow, and Pete Sampras will meet Vladimir Voltchkov, the first male qualifier to reach that round at Wimbledon since John McEnroe in 1977.
Venus and Serena Williams meet on Center Court today in a sister vs. sister semifinal match. Lindsay Davenport will face the 17-year-old prodigy Jelena Dokic.
Struggle Over Dance Legacy The Martha Graham Center of Contemporary Dance, which includes the dance company, is struggling to survive internecine warfare, nearly 10 years after its founder's death.
New Troupe for Tharp Twyla Tharp's new company makes its debut tonight, at the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C.

A Case Against Fertility Drugs A study confirmed that ovulation-inducing drugs carry a significant risk of producing unwanted multiple births, even when doctors carefully follow guidelines. Researchers suggested that doctors instead rely on in vitro fertilization.

2 Software Makers Stumble Shares of Computer Associates International and BMC Software, major business software companies, plunged in heavy trading after company warnings on earnings. They cited a slowdown in sales of software for mainframe computers.

Oil Dips to $30.67 a Barrel The price of crude oil dropped sharply after Saudi Arabia's statement on Monday that it was ready to pump 500,000 more barrels a day, but the price did not sink below the $30-a-barrel threshold. Traders and oil industry analysts said confusion remained in the market.

Phone Giants Bowing to Reality WorldCom and Sprint, facing resistance from regulators in the United States and Europe, plan to announce by early next week that they will abandon their $115 billion merger, executives close to both said.
Stocks Take a Downturn The Nasdaq fell 128.83 points, or 3.2 percent, to 3,863.10; the Dow lost 77.07, to 10,483.60; and the S.& P. 500 slid 23.09, to 1,446.23.
New Sign Economy Is Slowing The Index of Leading Economic Indicators declined by 0.1 percent in May, the latest indication that the Fed's string of interest rate increases had slowed the economy.
